replies.msg:
public place (公眾地方) means any place to which for the time being the public or any section of the public are entitled or permitted to have access, whether on payment or otherwise, and, in relation to any meeting, includes any place which is or will be, on the occasion and for the purposes of such meeting, a public place;

Under this definition, a shopping mall can be a public place because the public clearly have access. It does not matter whether it is a private premises, because the test is about access (ie. whether there is actual / implied consent).

replies.msg:
To further clarify, it doesn’t mean that “public place” carries the same meaning when POPO tries to stop and search / arrest people.

Stop and search / arrest are regulated by the Police Force Ordinance, where there is no definition for “public place”. So the test should be the one of control - shopping malls are fully managed and controlled by management so it is a private premises under PFO - consent is required before POPO enters into shopping malls.

But the Public Order Ordinance explicitly defines “public place” - the test is the one of consent, so shopping malls are, at least arguably, a public place under POO. It just means POO defines the term super broadly.
